name: Emily Keeble
bio:
PhD student in vertebrate palaeontology at Virginia Tech.
Embroidery: @flower.patches
🇬🇧 in 🇺🇲

social_posts.post_text:
Decided to post this one on the grid, actually 😅
.
My parents visited recently, and while visiting the Smithsonian Natural History Museum (and @paleontologica !) we spotted the two books I wrote pages for in the gift shop! Extremely cool to see!
.
I'm in the field currently and probably won't have any signal once we leave Texas and head to Arizona, but I'd really like to get back into posting again this summer, so hopefully stay tuned for that. Hope everyone is well and having a fossil filled summer!
.
.
.
.
@dkbooks #smithsonian #naturalhistorymuseum #writer #author #science #naturalhistory #museum

Greetings from the field! 
.
Finding fossils is great, but to do good science with them, we need to be careful about how we collect them. 
.
These are some 10 minute sketches I did of our field crew working to systematically collect #phytosaur materials. It was important to record where each person was collecting from, as it means that we can more easily identify chunks that may fit together based on proxemity when we come to unwrap and figure out exactly what we have. Definitely skull material though!
.
.
.
.
.
.
#fieldwork #fieldcrew #palaeontology #paleontologist #palaeontologist #paleontology #palaeo #sketch #fieldnotes

We've finished our time in Texas and are currently driving to Arizona! There's quite a bit of added weight to the vehicles with all the cool stuff we found.
.
One thing we found a lot of were phytosaurs. In the picture, I'm holding the quadrate and part of the quadratojugal - this is the part the skull that articulates with the lower jaw.
.
Phytosaurs were basically crocs before crocs were crocs. They look very similar, with the most obvious difference probably being the positioning of the nostrils. In crocodylians, the nostrils are at the end of the snout. In phytosaurs, the nostrils were up closer to the eyes.
.
.
.
.
.
#Phytosaurs #phytosaur #reptile #triassic #mesozoic #fossils #fossilhunting #fossil #paleontologist #palaeontology #palaeontologist #paleontology

There's still a few hours left of #InternationalDinosaurDay ! Celebrate with me and this absolutely stunning Ghost Ranch #Coelophysis block I saw earlier this year in the collections of @carnegiemnh . Sadly, I didn't find any dinosaurs in the field today, but I did find lots of other awesome #Triassic fossils!
.
Coelophysis was an early #dinosaur known from the Late Triassic of southwestern USA. One of the most prolific Coelophysis localities is Ghost Ranch, a site in New Mexico and former home of artist Georgia O'Keeffe. This site has yielded hundreds of skeletons of gorgeously preserved Coelophysis, which dominate the fauna of the assemblage. The downside is that these specimens do not CT scan well, which makes my life a bit harder when it comes time to process any scans from the locality!
.
Happy Dinosaur Day!
.
.
.
.
.
#GhostRanch #dinosaurs #theropods #paleontologist #palaeontology #palaeontologist #paleontology #mesozoic #DinosaurDay

One of my favourite types of critter to find out here in petrified forest are aetosaurs.
.
We commonly find their osteoderms, and occasionally other bits and pieces (next to no definite teeth though... Hopefully my dissertation work can help up this number).
.
This guy in particular is a mount of Longosuchus in the Royal Ontario Museum. #Longosuchus , like other aetosaurs, is known from the Late Triassic only. Longosuchus has been recorded from North America and north Africa.
.
.
.
.
.
#Triassic #mesozoic #paleontologist #palaeontology #palaeontologist #paleontology #archosaur #pseudosuchia #aetosaur #museum #rom

Happy #FossilFriday ! We're nearing the end of fieldwork here in the Late Triassic, so I thought one of its most famous occupants: Postosuchus.
.
This large rausuchid predator was first known from Dockum Group sediments near the town of Post, Texas, hence the name. Much larger than the dinosaurs it shared its environment with, this pseudosuchian (crocodile line archosaur) would have been an apex predator on land.
.
We've found a few rausuchid teeth, but nothing that can definitively be assigned to #Postosuchus. Maybe next year...
.
.
.
.
.
#Triassic #mesozoic #paleontologist #palaeontology #palaeontologist #paleontology #pseudosuchia #rausuchid #petrifiedforest #PEFO

I couldn't let today go by without saying a happy 30th birthday to the Jurassic Park movie! This film series has had such a huge influence on my, and many other palaeontologists around my ages, lives. Though I always loved dinosaurs, it's hard to say if I would still be here without this franchise!
.
Jurassic Park was absolutely revolutionary for its time, featuring some of the latest ideas in #palaeontology and changing the public's perception of #dinosaurs forever. It inspired a huge new wave of palaeontologists (and funding) to enter the field, and can probably take some credit for revitalising dinosaur palaeobiology, of course alongside many exciting discoveries that happened around the same time.
.
T. rex is the icon of the series, so here is one that I saw at the Carnegie Museum earlier this year.
.
#HappyBirthdayJurassicPark !
.
.
.
.
#JurassicPark #JurassicWorld #cretaceous #mesozoic #trex #tyrannosaurusrex #tyrannosaurus #carnegiemuseumofnaturalhistory #dinosaurs #dino #paleontologist #palaeontologist #paleontology

Sometimes palaeontology is hiking through spectacular landscapes, or digging with pick and hammer in a quarry, aaaand sometimes it is... this.
.
I did an awful lot of lying in the dirt, doing my best impression of a slug this year. There is a reason though! This is the best way to surface collect microfossils. These fossils can be so tiny that the only way to spot them is to put your nose to the ground and crawl. The things we find during screen washing can be even smaller!
.
.
.
.
#paleontologist #palaeontology #palaeontologist #paleontology #fossilhunting #fossils #fieldwork #microfossils

I bought an @fujifilm_instax_northamerica instant camera on an impulse the day before we left for the field and it was an EXCELLENT DECISION. Here are some of the adorable photos I got of the trip featuring prospecting, digging, landscapes, museums, and cooking, and close ups of a few of my faves.
.
The camera held up super well despite the heat, bight sunlight, and dust. Now I want a larger one...
.
.
.
.
#instax #instaxmini #instaxmini12 #paleontologist #palaeontology #palaeontologist #paleontology #paleo #fieldwork #polaroid #instantcamera #prospecting #vtgeoscience #virginiatech

I'm on another long bus journey - here's a very big hint, dug up from the archives, to where I'm off to this time, a very recognisable museum.
.
This is Prestosuchus, a loricatan like Postosuchus that I posted about the other week, known from the Middle Triassic of Brazil. It was one of the larger members of the group and is estimated to have been 5 to potentially up to 7 meters long. It was definitely a top predator in its time!
.
One thing that rather tickled me is that there is a specimen known with palpebral bones! These are osteoderm bones that cover the eyelids. They are known in several groups of animals, though it's unclear of the homology (a feature shared ancestrally) of this bone. One of the most notable living examples I know is Cuvier's dwarf caiman, which has the scientific name Paleosuchus palpebrosus thanks to its really large triangular palpebrals.
.
It tickles me because the word is really fun to say.
.
.
.
.
.
#SpoilerItsTheAMNH #AMNH #prestosuchus #loricata #archosaur #paleontologist #palaeontology #palaeontologist #paleontology #fossils #fossil #Triassic #mesozoic

Happy Shark Week everyone! I can't say that I've actually ever watched any of Discovery's programming for the week (do we even have shark week in the UK?) but it's a great excuse to post #megalodon pics. And then to watch one of the classics; like Megashark Vs Crocosaurus, Sharknado, and/or Sharktopus.
.
This is a bit of a throwback picture now: it was taken during a break at SVP last year when I went to check out the aquarium with friends. I was delighted to see this megalodon jaw reproduction in the lobby. Megalodon was the largest #shark that ever lived, swimming in the seas of the #Miocene to #Pliocene
.
As is obligatory to say whenever posting meg: yes, it is definitely extinct.
.
.
.
.
#chondrichthyes #fossils #paleontologist #palaeontology #aquarium #palaeontologist #paleontology #Otodus #otodusmegalodon

*goes to any museum*
"Hi, I'm interested in looking at Triassic archosaurs that have teeth preserved in their skulls"
"Excellent! May I direct you to our collection of Coelophysis skulls from Ghost Ranch?"

I meant it when I said HUNDREDS of #Coelophysis were recovered from this site! This one in particular is a relatively large (though definitely not the largest) skull that is housed in the collections at the American Museum of Natural History, which I visited a few weeks ago. Hopefully I get to use the existing CT scan of this guy as I made a note of all the different tooth characters (distinctive features of the teeth eg. serrations and where these serrations are). Characters like these are often used in phylogenetic analyses, or in my case, I'm going to compare how similar/different these teeth are with other carnivorous Triassic archosauromorphs (which is basically what you do in phylogenetic analysis, but whatever).
.
.
.
.
.
.
#dinosaurs #dino #dinosaur #theropods #theropod #AMNH #americanmuseumofnaturalhistory #Triassic #mesozoic #fossils #FossilFriday

location.city_name: Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History

social_posts.post_text:
Do you ever feel
like a fossil thing
with your skull caved in
wanting to start again?
.
.
Relating hard to this cast of the early tetrapodomorph Acanthostega in @smithsoniannmnh with a hole in the top of its head this week - thwacked my head on the ramp at the skate park resulting in a mild concussion whoops. Wear your helmet kids! Would have been a lot worse if I hadn't been.
.
.
But anyway, no one is here for that. Acanthostega is one of our vital "transitional fossils" in the story of vertebrates emerging from the water to colonise the land over 350 million years ago. Probably over 400 million years ago based on footprint evidence. #Acanthostega is one of the first body fossils with pretty much fully developed limbs as opposed to fins - though they still most likely weren't really adapted to walking on land. I always found it cool that these early tetrapodomorphs had way more digits than tetrapods today (Acanthostega had 8 on its hands), which makes sense given they evolved from fins.
.
.
.
.
.
.
#tetrapod #tetrapodomorph #amphibian #smithsonian #evolution #transitionalfossils #missinglink #FossilFriday #paleontologist #palaeontology #palaeontologist #paleontology #paleo #palaeozoic #devonian

If I'm going to have a concussion, I'm going to milk it for content. So have a Pachycephalosaurus.
.
.
#Pachycephalosaurus was certainly more built for head trauma than I am, with a built in helmet, the dome on it's skull, that could be 25cm thick. Despite us knowing about the skull from which it takes its name (thick headed lizard - also a pretty good insult) for over 80 years, the purpose of the dome is still somewhat debated. It is of course famous for being depicted as getting into headbutting matches, but it's also been considered that perhaps the dome was just for display (probably not its only use, but it likely signalled maturity as it greatly enlarged through ontogeny/growth), or maybe they were only running into each others flanks rather than head on collisions. Intraspecific headbutting (or both kinds of combat) is definitely not out of the question though!
.
.
Good evidence for headbutting comes from frequent instances of osteomyelitis recognised in dome fossils - this is a bone infection that can be caused by trauma to the overlying tissue, or to the bone itself. In all 22% of domes were found to have this infection, mostly a the apex of the dome, and flat headed juvenile morphs lacked any lesions. (Peterson et al. 2013)
.
.
A cool thing about the domes is because they are essentially just hunks of solid bone they preserve reasonably well, even when the rest of the skull is gone. Decently preserved skulls of pachycephalosaurs are rare but the domes by themselves can be found more frequently if you're lucky and happen to be wandering through the Hell Creek Formation.
.
.
.
Paper (open access!): Peterson et al. 2013. Distributions of cranial pathologies provide evidence for head-butting in dome headed dinosaurs (Pachycephalosauridae). PLoS One 8(7)
.
.
.
.
.
#paleontologist #palaeontology #palaeontologist #paleontology #paleo #dino #dinosaurs #dinosaur #fossils #fossil #Cretaceous #mesozoic #dinosaurfossil

One thing successful vertebrate palaeontologists have to be good at is anatomy, and so we spend a lot of time studying this. Understanding what bones go where and how to tell them apart are vital parts of being able to reconstruct ancient life, especially when no modern analogues exist. The good thing about vertebrates is that once you get a good understanding of the skeleton, for the most part they follow the same pattern, and outliers can be diagnostic of a group (for example, the predentary bone in ornithischian dinosaurs).
.
.
Here's one part of that study: this is a 3D print of the #skull of Dippy the #Diplodocus (which you can also download for free on the London NHM's Sketchfab page!). This was an exercise for class, and I wanted to do a clade of dinosaurs whose skull anatomy I'm a little less familiar with and thought that I'd never really seen a clear diagram of #sauropod skull bones that would be easily utilised as a teaching tool. The different colours of paint match a key that the whole class followed so all of our skulls are consistent. I had fun painting this (even if I asked the people in the printing lab to print it as large as they could and in a light colour and they handed me back a small, dark brown skull...) and it helped that I had a sauropod expert check it over!
.
.
.
.
.
#dino #dinosaurs #dinosaur #paleontologist #palaeontology #palaeontologist #paleontology #paleo #saurischian #jurassic #mesozoic #anatomy #osteology #phdlife #gradschool

It's SVP time and I found my boy!
.
This week I'm at the Society of Vertebrate Paleontology annual meeting. I've already seen some great talks about fantastic research and it's only the first day! Here's me in the poster/vendor hall holding a Deinonychus skull replica made by @skullsunlimited . It's beautiful but a bit out of my budget 😅
.
Come and say hi if you're also in Cincinnati for the meeting, and come and see my talk! It's my first full length talk at a major conference so if seeing a very nervous person stumble through a talk, or perhaps even the dental morphology of archosaurs esp. aetosaurs, then I look forward to seeing you at 8:45 on Friday 
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
#SVP #societyofvertebratepaleontology #svp2023 #2023SVP #paleontologist #palaeontology #palaeontologist #paleontology #dinosaurfossil #dino #dinosaur #Deinonychus #raptor #dromaeosaur #mesozoic #Cretaceous

[Frodo voice, with all the weariness of someone who crossed Middle Earth in a perilous journey to ascend a volcano and throw an evil ring into the fires of Mount Doom, losing a finger in the process and almost died] It's done....
.
SVP 2023 is officially over! It was really good to see friends old and new! I was also super excited to see this Dilophosaurus bust puppet by @brianengh_art in real life! I'm pretty confident in saying that this sculpture is the most up to date and rigorously reconstructed model of #Dilophosaurus out there. Dilophosaurus was one of the earliest larger (though definitely not among the largest) theropods, having lived in the Early Jurassic. It was considerably bigger than the little gals in Jurassic Park.
.
Obligatory "there is no evidence that it had a frill and/or spat venom"
.
Safe journey home to anyone I didn't manage to catch and say goodbye to at the after party!
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
#dino #dinosaurs #dinosaur #JurassicPark #JurassicWorld #jurassic #mesozoic #theropod #paleontologist #palaeontologist #palaeontology #paleontology #palaeoart #svp2023 #SVP #2023SVP

Beelzebufo! The devil toad!
.
You may remember this large lad from the objectively best moment of Prehistoric Planet II (taking place in Late Cretaceous Madagascar) and so I was delighted to see this replica by @fossilcrates at SVP.
.
I love #frog skeletons. They really said "I don't need anything but a head and legs". They have 9 or fewer vertebrae in their bodies for goodness sake. The pelvis is also highly modified to better enable jumping, being extremely elongate. #Beelzebufo was one of, if not the largest frog ever. Current specimens are around the size of an African bullfrog, but the unfused cranial bones of the largest suggest that it wasn't done growing, and could have gotten bigger.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
#svp2023 #svp #2023SVP #Cretaceous #mesozoic #paleontologist #palaeontology #palaeontologist #paleontology #amphibian #lissamphibia

I haven't posted the dunk in aaaaaages, but I got to say hello to the awesome Cleveland Shale skull while at SVP.
.
The dunk (better known as Dunkleosteus) was a gigantic placoderm fish from the Devonian Period. Placoderms are predominantly known from their thick, boney skulls and "neck" shields as the rest of their skeleton was composed of cartilage. This can make reconstructing the postcrania a little tricky.
.
When we are missing large parts of a fossil's anatomy, we have to turn to more complete specimens of its close relatives. This has produced estimates that put dunk at a possible 10 meters! However, it's now mostly agreed that this is very unlikely, and 6 meters or less is much more probable. At SVP last year, Engelman first presented research (now published) that shrunk the dunk further, based on the typically deeper bodies of other placoderms, and estimated a length of 4.1 meters for the largest specimen.
.
.
Paper (open access!): Engelman, R.K. 2023. A Devonian Fish Tale: A New Method of Body Length Estimation Suggests Much Smaller Sizes for Dunkleosteus terrelli (Placodermi: Arthrodira). Diversity 15(3)
.
.
.
.
.
#Dunkleosteus #placoderm #fish #paleontologist #palaeontology #palaeontologist #paleontology #palaeozoic #devonian #fossils #fossil #cincinnatimuseumcenter

Spent a little while absolutely losing my mind at the prep on this GIGANTIC crinoid block in the Cincinnati Museum Centre that I saw at the SVP welcome reception.
.
These delicate stems and fronds look an awful lot like plants, but they are in fact the remains of echinoderm animals. Having been a staple of our oceans since at least the Ordovician and are still present today as sea lilies and feather stars.
.
.
.
.
.
#crinoid #cincinnatimuseumcenter #echinoderm #mesozoic #fossils #paleontologist #palaeontology #palaeontologist #paleontology #paleo #invertebrates

I absolutely HAD to get a photo with the incredible Deinonychus puppet/costume that Sam (not on IG) has made at #SVP
.
The costume is meticulously designed, following the latest research on what we believe #Deinonychus looked like. While we don't know what colours it would have been (though funnily we do know what colour it's eggs were - blue) we know based on where it sits in the #dinosaur family tree that it would have had a full coat of feathers (represented here by the fur. I shudder to think how expensive and difficult it would have been to use actual feathers).
.
Can't wait to see how Sam's costume will have grown next year!!
.
.
.
.
.
#palaeoart #dromaeosaur #theropod #paleontologist #palaeontology #palaeontologist #paleontology #paleo #svp2023 #2023SVP #Cretaceous

Do you ever see something incredibly cool and then totally forget to post about it for months? Yeah me either. 

Anyway, here is the dentary (lower jaw bone) of the holotype of the tyrannical reptile itself, Tyrannosaurus rex that I got the chance to see in the collections of the Carnegie Museum way back in January. This was the first animal named T. rex (though not the first specimen discovered - that one’s in the London NHM and I believe there’s a picture of me with it further down my feed haha. Although I suppose the REAL first is that partial vertebra in the AMNH…). 

The bones are beautifully preserved, as many are from the Hell Creek formation in Montana - just check out those tooth serrations on the last slide. It was such a cool specimen to see up close and to touch!

I’ve built up a fair few pictures in the archives so expect to see photos from many moons ago…

#Trex #tyrannosaurus #cretaceous #mesozoic #palaeontology #palaeontologist #paleontology #paleontologist #theropod #dino #dinosaur #fossil

As I’m heading back to the UK for the holidays soon, here are some pictures from what I got up to last year: FINALLY visiting @tec_kimmeridge (well, in its form as a fancy museum - I saw the collection as a masters student when it was just in Steve’s house). 

This museum is well worth a visit if you find yourself on the Jurassic Coast. I’ve focused on a couple of ichthyosaurs (and me feat. whopping pliosaur jaws) but there is so much more cool stuff to see and learn - all collected and prepared by Steve Etches and now on display for all to see. 

Ichthyosaurs were marine reptiles whose heyday was in the Jurassic. While they lived alongside dinosaurs, they were not dinosaurs, and while they went all in on that fish shape, they were still reptiles and so had to breathe air. It’s not too uncommon to find the odd #ichthyosaur bone along the Jurassic Coast (I mean, I still haven’t managed it but…) but these specimens are exceptional. 

#etchescollection #marinereptile #JurassicCoast #Jurassic #mesozoic #palaeontology #palaeontologist #paleontology #paleontologist

location.city_name: Oxford University Museum of Natural History

social_posts.post_text:
In my last museum visit of the year, I visited the Oxford University Museum of Zoology on behalf of one of the other VT PhD students who does not have the good fortune of their childhood home being less than three hours from Oxford. 

The entire trip was based around photographing this one specimen, which has been featured in the literature as a drawing (Renesto & Fraser 2003) (which I looked at and said “I can do better”) but never photographed - something that would be very useful for someone investigating the #homology of (in this case what bones formed) this element. 

“But why would we care about the homology of a claw? It’s just a normal ungual.” Ohohoho you would think, but this particular claw is from the Triassic, which basically automatically makes it weird. More than that, it’s from an animal called a drepanosaur, which makes it Weird. 

#Drepanosaurs were small to smallish reptiles, many of which were arboreal (lived in trees) and they are notoriously strange little guys. Their skulls were almost bird-like, but attached to a quadrupedal body with a large hump at the shoulders. Many had one ENORMOUS claw (and also normal sized claws) on their hands, and the bones between/of the hand and the shoulder were… look I don’t like to use a word too much in quick succession, but they were weird. Some featured completely prehensile tails, which ended in what you see above: a claw. 

Drepanosaurs were the only tetrapods to grow a #claw on the end of their tails, hence why it’s homology is interesting to palaeontologists! The function of the claw isn’t quite clear (help gripping branches? Defence???) but Isaac is working on it!

Paper: Renesto and Fraser 2003. Drepanosaurid (Reptilia: Diapsida) remains from a Late Triassic fissure infilling at Cromhall Quarry (Avon, Great Britain)

#reptile #drepanosaurus #palaeontologists #palaeontology #paleontologist #paleontology #Triassic #mesozoic #fossil #fossils

It’s annual new year’s/birthday recap post time! It almost felt like I did hardly anything this year, but turns out I did in fact get up to a decent amount of stuff!

Top row:
✨ I started the year with a less successful than I had hoped trip to @natural_history_museum - it got cut short due to train strikes, but I’m back in a few days to make up for it!
✨ I finally made my way to Kimmeridge and @tec_kimmeridge what a fantastic little museum!
✨ once I got back to the states, it was almost straight to @carnegiemnh for a lab trip to the collections 

Middle row:
✨ I got to go on a few nice hikes this year, this picture is from when my parents visited and we walked to the Cascades 
✨ of course, there was fieldwork in the summer in Texas and at @petrifiedforestnps I truly do not think I’ve ever gone longer between showers. 
✨ seeing as I was going to New York anyway, I arranged to check out some Triassic material @amnh and it was my first time handling Antarctic fossils (I am always available for an an expedition to Antarctica, fyi)

Bottom row:
✨ and then it was SVP time! I got to meet so many cool people from here in real life, and I gave my first full talk at a major conference!
✨ on the way back we went to see Mothman in Point Pleasant. It was bangin
✨ and most recently, as you may have seen in my last post, I got to visit the collections at Cambridge and see the museums!

I think it’s obvious that I have a backlog of things to post about, so stick around if you want to learn more next year! I’m off to eat a concerning volume of delicious Nepalese food to get my strength up for visiting collections and a conference before the long journey back to Virginia. Happy New Year!

I’m not going to talk about it. 

(okay, will a tiny bit because this is an educational account. Basically a new paper dropped claiming that Nanotyrannus is a valid genus. This is an extremely contentious subject in dinosaur palaeontology, hence my wanting to avoid it lol. This is a cast of Jane, a juvenile T. rex to whom the nano genus has been applied)

#dinosaur #palaeontology #palaeontologist #paleontologist #paleontology #fossils #dinosaurfossil #Trex #tyrannosaurus #nanotyrannus

Happy first #FossilFriday of the year! Here’s me with a really awesome #dinosaur skull that I took a look at while I’ve been in the collections of @natural_history_museum this week.

This is the holotype skull of Proceratosaurus. As some of you may have guessed, it was named so as it was originally thought to be an ancestor of Ceratosaurus. This name means “horn lizard” thanks to the little crest on its snoot. Comparisons were made between that and the partially preserved crest on the skull of #Proceratosaurus and that was that. (Although, as I’m sure you will be shocked to learn, this Jurassic, British theropod was originally described as Megalosaurus. Absolutely no one could have seen that coming). 

However, today Proceratosaurus is considered to be a basal member of Tyrannosauroidea, the clade that also includes Tyrannosaurus rex and many other famous dinosaurs. This deduction was made possible by CT scans and what I can only assume was absolutely terrifying additional preparation. 

If you want to check out the skull in more detail, the Natural History Museum has a 3D model of it on their Sketchfab page! This model was actually being processed when I first started volunteering at the museum, so it was really cool to see again. 

#dinosaurs #tyrannosauroidea #theropod #palaeontology #palaeontologist #paleontologist #paleontology #fossil #fossils #dinosaurskull #jurassic #mesozoic

PhD student in vertebrate palaeontology at Virginia Tech.
